trans-unit.source: This function sets the way the edges of a Framebuffer are treated if it is scaled or rotated. If the WrapMode is set to 'clamp', the edge will not be interpolated. If set to 'repeat', the edge will be interpolated with the pixels on the opposing side of the framebuffer.
This function terminates the thread wherever it is, which is capable of locking the game, or doing anything evil for that matter, its use is strongly discouraged.
This function will clear the target framebuffer.
This function will not accumulate anything; any impulses previously applied since the last call to World:update will be lost.
This function will not accumulate anything; any impulses previously applied since the last call to World:update will be lost.
This function will only pause the specified Source.
This function will only stop the specified source.
This function will pause all currently active Sources.
This function will pause all execution of the main thread until the user has clicked a button to exit the message box. Calling the function from a different thread may cause love to crash.
This function will stop all currently active sources.
This function, depending on the compression format and level, can be slow if called repeatedly, such as from love.update or love.draw. Some benchmarks are available here.
This functionality is not supported in earlier versions.
This functions returns the currently set horizontal and vertical wrapping modes for the framebuffer.
This is different from RandomGenerator:getSeed in that getState gets the RandomGenerator's current state, whereas getSeed gets the previously set seed number.
This is different from RandomGenerator:setSeed in that setState directly sets the RandomGenerator's current implementation-dependent state, whereas setSeed gives it a new seed value.
This is important because the physics in Box2D is tuned to work well for objects of size 0.1m up to 10m. All physics coordinates are divided by this number for the physics calculations.
This is particularly useful for mouse interaction with the shapes. By looping through all shapes and testing the mouse position with this function, we can find which shapes the mouse touches.
This is the full source for 'hello world' in LÖVE. Running this code will cause an 800 by 600 window to appear, and display white text on a black background.

This is used to convert coordinates from the size users are expecting them to display at onscreen to pixels. love.window.fromPixels does the opposite. The highdpi window flag must be enabled to use the full pixel density of a Retina screen on Mac OS X and iOS. The flag currently does nothing on Windows and Linux, and on Android it is effectively always enabled.
This joint actually connects the body to a fixed point in the world. To make it follow the mouse, the fixed point must be updated every timestep (example below).
This joint connects two bodies to a point around which they can pivot.

This joint constrains the distance between two points on two bodies to be constant. These two points are specified in world coordinates and the two bodies are assumed to be in place when this joint is created. The first anchor point is connected to the first body and the second to the second body, and the points define the length of the distance joint.
This library provides basic support for handling UTF-8 encoded strings.
This makes all the sprite's vertices equal (because the x and y scales are 0), which prevents the GPU from fully processing the sprite when drawing the SpriteBatch.
This may be different than the number used as an argument to love.graphics.newCanvas if the system running LÖVE doesn't support that number.
This method avoids that issue by making sure the Thread calling the method has exclusive access to the Channel until the specified function has returned.

This method can be slow if the Mesh has a large number of vertices. Keep the original table used to create the Mesh around and update it when necessary instead of using this method frequently, if possible.
This method for retrieving errors has been replaced by Thread:getError and love.threaderror.
This method is not supported in earlier or later versions.
This method is not supported in earlier versions.
This method is not supported in that and later versions.
This module is not supported in earlier versions.
This module is responsible for decoding and streaming video files.
This module is responsible for decoding sound files.
This module is responsible for decoding sound files. It can't play the sounds, see love.audio for that.
This module is responsible for decoding, controlling, and streaming video files.
This module provides access to files in specific places:
This object is not supported in earlier versions.
This shader variable is not supported in earlier versions.
This shape can have 8 vertices at most, and must form a convex shape.
This shape is not supported in earlier versions.
This takes into account the time spent updating and drawing each frame.
This type is not supported in earlier or later versions.
This type is not supported in earlier versions.
This value can also be set by the fourth argument of Body:setMass.

This variant creates a new font using the default font and the size specified, and sets it as the current font. Do not use this function in love.update or love.draw. That would create a new font every frame, eating up memory very quickly.
This variant is not supported in earlier or later versions.
This variant is not supported in earlier versions.
This variant is not supported in that and later versions.
This variant is not used in that and later versions..
This variant uses the default font (Vera Sans) with a custom size.
This will return true inside the callbacks from World:setCallbacks.
Though be wary that host:service() and peer:recieve() can return nil if no events are in the queue.

Threads are separate Lua environments, running in parallel to the main code. As their code runs separately, they can be used to compute complex operations without adversely affecting the frame rate of the main thread. However, as they are separate environments, they cannot access the variables and functions of the main thread, and communication between threads is limited.
Threads which are not running can be (re)started with Thread:start.
Time in milliseconds to wait before automatically calling peer:ping().
Time since the last update in seconds.
Timeout value, in milliseconds, that a reliable packet has to be acknowledged if the variable timeout limit was exceeded before dropping the peer.
To delete the reference, explicitly pass nil.

To use a custom named vertex attribute in a Vertex Shader, it must be declared as an attribute variable of the same name. Variables can be sent from Vertex Shader code to Pixel Shader code by making a varying variable. For example:
Toggle between point styles with the help of love.graphics.getPointStyle.
Toggle between point styles with the help of love.graphics.setPointStyle.
Toggle mouse visibility by pressing tab (using setVisible).
Toggle mouse visibility by pressing tab.
Toggles an adaptive order-2 PPMrange coder for the transmitted data of all peers.
Toggles an adaptive order-2 PPM range coder for the transmitted data of all peers.
Toggles whether the mouse is grabbed by pressing tab, using love.mouse.setGrabbed.
Toggles whether the mouse is grabbed by pressing tab, with the help of love.mouse.isGrabbed.
Torque is like a force that will change the angular velocity (spin) of a body. The effect will depend on the rotational inertia a body has.
Transform a point from local coordinates to world coordinates.
Transform a point from world coordinates to local coordinates.
Transform a vector from local coordinates to world coordinates.
Transform a vector from world coordinates to local coordinates.
Transform an image by applying a function to every pixel.
Transforms multiple points from local coordinates to world coordinates.
Translate down and to the right by 10 pixels. Remember, the translation is reset at the end of each love.draw.
Translates the World's origin. Useful in large worlds where floating point precision issues become noticeable at far distances from the origin.
Translates the coordinate system in two dimensions.
Translates the shape along the x-axis.
Translates the shape along the y-axis.
Translating using whole numbers will prevent tearing/blurring of images and fonts draw after translating.
Transparent backgrounds are currently not supported.
True for the Bodies to collide, false otherwise.
True if high-dpi mode is allowed on Retina displays in OS X. Does nothing on non-Retina displays. Added in 0.9.1.
True if high-dpi mode should be used on Retina displays in OS X and iOS. Does nothing on non-Retina displays. Added in 0.9.1.
True if LÖVE should wait for vsync, false otherwise.
True if any specified button is down, false otherwise.
True if any specified button is down.
True if any supplied Scancode is down, false if not.
True if any supplied button is down, false if not.
True if any supplied key is down, false if not.
True if bodies in the world are allowed to sleep, or false if not.
True if enabled, false if disabled.
True if everything is supported, false otherwise.
True if gamma-correct rendering is supported and was enabled in love.conf, false otherwise.
True if inside, false if outside
True if no more particles can be added, false otherwise.
True if per-vertex coloring is used, otherwise love.graphics.setColor is used when drawing the Mesh.
True if relative mode is enabled, false if it's disabled.
True if relative particle rotation is enabled, false if it's disabled.
True if rumble / force feedback vibration is supported on this Joystick, false if not.
True if supported, false if not.
True if system display sleep is enabled / allowed, false otherwise.
True if system is active, false otherwise.
True if system is paused, false otherwise.
True if system is stopped, false otherwise.
True if the Joystick is currently connected, false otherwise.
True if the Joystick is recognized as a gamepad, false otherwise.
True if the Source is paused, false otherwise.
True if the Source is playing, false otherwise.
True if the Source is static, false otherwise.
True if the Source is stopped, false otherwise.
True if the Source will loop, false otherwise.
True if the archive was successfully mounted, false otherwise.
True if the archive was successfully unmounted, false otherwise.
True if the bodies are allowed to sleep or false if not.
True if the body is active or false if not.
True if the body is allowed to sleep or false if not.
True if the body is awake or false if not.
True if the body's rotation is locked or false if not.
True if the button is down, false if it is not
True if the compression algorithm is active, false if not.
True if the cursor is grabbed, false if it is not.
True if the cursor to visible, false if the cursor is hidden.
True if the directory was created, false if not.
True if the file is currently open, false otherwise.
True if the file/directory was removed, false otherwise.
True if the game is in fused mode, false otherwise.
True if the graphics framerate is synchronized with the monitor's refresh rate, false otherwise.
True if the image's pixels should be interpreted as being linear RGB rather than sRGB-encoded, if gamma-correct rendering is enabled. Has no effect otherwise.
True if the joystick has been successfully opened or false on failure.
True if the joystick is open, false if it is closed.
True if the key is down, false if not.
True if the mouse button press originated from a touchscreen touch-press.
True if the mouse button release originated from a touchscreen touch-release.
True if the object is of the specified type, false otherwise.
True if the operation was successful, or nil if there was an error.
True if the path is a symbolic link, false otherwise.
True if the point is inside or false if it is outside.
True if the position, velocity, direction and cone angles are relative to the listener, false if they're absolute.
True if the source should loop, false otherwise.
True if the specified button is down.
True if the thread is running, false otherwise.
True if the vibration was successfully applied, false if not.
True if the vibration was successfully disabled, false if not.
True if the window gains focus, false if it loses focus.
True if the window has been created, false otherwise.
True if the window has mouse focus or false if not.
True if the window has the focus or false if not.
True if the window is borderless in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window is centered in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window is currently maximized in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window is fullscreen, false otherwise.
True if the window is open, false otherwise.
True if the window is resizable in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window is visible or false if not.
True if the window is visible, false if it isn't.
True if the window should be borderless in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window should be centered in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if the window should be resizable in windowed mode, false otherwise.
True if there are no live particles, false otherwise.
True if there is a directory with the specified name. False otherwise.
True if there is a file or directory with the specified name. False otherwise.
True if there is a file with the specified name. False otherwise.
True if they collide, false otherwise.
True if they touch or false if not.
True if vertical sync is enabled or false if disabled.
True if wireframe lines are used when drawing, false if it's not.
True to check for fullscreen, false for windowed.
True to confine the mouse, false to let it leave the window.
True to enable or false to disable.
True to enable relative mode, false to disable it.
True to enable relative particle rotation, false to disable it.
True to enable system display sleep, false to disable it.
True to enable wireframe mode when drawing, false to disable it.
True to enable, false to disable.
True to flip horizontally, false to leave as-is.
True to flip vertically, false to leave as-is.
True to make the position, velocity, direction and cone angles relative to the listener, false to make them absolute.
True to preserve old stencil values of pixels, false to re-set every pixel's stencil value to 0 before executing the stencil function. love.graphics.clear will also re-set all stencil values.
True to set the cursor to visible, false to hide the cursor.
True to use per-vertex coloring, otherwise love.graphics.setColor is used when drawing.
True turns the motor on and false turns it off.
True when the body is allowed to sleep.
Two channels (red and green components) with 8 bits per channel (16 bpp).
Two ways of drawing the same triangle
Types of message box dialogs. Different types may have slightly different looks.
Types of particle area spread distribution.
Types of system-dependent graphics limits checked for using love.graphics.getSystemLimits.
Unicode text input is now handled separately via love.textinput.

Uniform / extern variables are read-only in the shader code and remain constant until modified by a Shader:send call. Uniform variables can be accessed in both the Vertex and Pixel components of a shader, as long as the variable is declared in each.
Unique ID that was assigned to the connection.
Unique instance identifier. Changes every time the Joystick is reconnected. nil if the Joystick is not connected.
Unless you define the love.threaderror callback or call Thread:getError you won't see any errors your thread code throws.

Unlike key constants, Scancodes are keyboard layout-independent. For example the scancode "w" will be generated if the key in the same place as the "w" key on an American keyboard is pressed, no matter what the key is labelled or what the user's operating system settings are.

Unlike key constants, Scancodes are keyboard layout-independent. For example the scancode "w" will be generated if the key in the same place as the "w" key on an American keyboard is pressed, no matter what the key is labelled or what the user's operating system settings are.

Unlike regular KeyConstants, Scancodes are keyboard layout-independent. The scancode "w" is used if the key in the same place as the "w" key on an American keyboard is pressed, no matter what the key is labelled or what the user's operating system settings are.
Unlike the PolygonShape, the ChainShape does not have a vertices limit or has to form a convex shape, but self intersections are not supported.

Unlike traditional PNG or jpeg, these formats stay compressed in RAM and in the graphics card's VRAM. This is good for saving memory space as well as improving performance, since the graphics card will be able to keep more of the image's pixels in its fast-access cache when drawing it.
Unmounts a zip file or folder previously mounted for reading with love.filesystem.mount.
Unmounts a zip file or folder previously mounted with love.filesystem.mount.
Up vector of the listener orientation.
Update the state of the world.
Updates the particle system; moving, creating and killing particles.
Upstream bandwidth in bytes/sec. Defaults to 0 (unlimited).
Usage hints for SpriteBatches and Meshes to optimize data storage and access.
Usage hints for SpriteBatches and Meshes.
Use Body:getLocalCenter to get the center of mass in local coordinates.
Use Body:getWorldCenter to get the center of mass in world coordinates.
Use love.wheelmoved to detect mouse wheel motion. It will not register as a button press in version 0.10.0 and newer.
Use Mesh:getVertex in a loop instead.
Use Mesh:setTexture if the Mesh should be textured with an Image or Canvas when it's drawn.
Use a Quad to display part of an Image:
Use a vertex map to fix a visual glitch without copy/pasting vertices.
Use at your own risk. Directly reading from and writing to the raw memory owned by the Data will bypass any safety checks and thread-safety the Data might normally have.
Use getPosition to help draw a custom mouse image
Use newFont to draw a custom styled text
Use periods to seperate folders. If the module is a lua file, don't use the .lua extension in the string passed to require.
Use sleep to cap FPS at 30
Use this function in one thread and one thread only. Using it in more threads will make Lua cry and most likely crash.
Used to create cool effects, like fire.

Using a single image, draw any number of identical copies of the image using a single call to love.graphics.draw(). This can be used, for example, to draw repeating copies of a single background image with high performance.
Using an Image as a stencil mask
Using an anonymous function for drawing to a Canvas
Using an anonymous function for drawing to a Framebuffer

Using scancodes, rather than keycodes, is useful because keyboards with layouts differing from the US/UK layout(s) might have keys that generate 'unknown' keycodes, but the scancodes will still be detected. This however would necessitate having a list for each keyboard layout one would choose to support.
Valid x and y values start at 0 and go up to canvas width and height minus 1.
Valid x and y values start at 0 and go up to image width and height minus 1.
Validates whether the PolygonShape is convex.
Validates whether the PolygonShape is convex. Concave PolygonShapes cannot be used in love.physics.
Value used to determine whether the image should use more or less detailed mipmap levels than normal when drawing.
Versions prior to 0.8.0 have Framebuffers that are susceptible to power of 2 syndrome.
Vertex and Pixel shader code can be combined into one file or string if you wrap the vertex-specific code in #ifdef VERTEX .. #endif and the pixel-specific code in #ifdef PIXEL .. #endif.

Vertex shader code is run for every vertex drawn to the screen (for example, love.graphics.rectangle will produce 4 vertices) and is used to transform the vertex positions from their original coordinates into screen-space, as well as to send information such as per-vertex color and texture coordinate values to the pixel shader.
Vertex shader code must contain at least one function, named position, which is the function that will produce transformed vertex positions of drawn objects in screen-space.
Vertexes are returned starting from the bottom-left in a clockwise fashion (bottom-left, top-left, top-right, bottom-right).
Vertical wrapping mode of the Canvas.
Vertical wrapping mode of the Framebuffer.
Vertical wrapping mode of the framebuffer.
Vertical wrapping mode of the image.
WARNING: LÖVE 0.6.2 does not yet contain the fix for a bug with this function when it is called with a false argument.
Wait for events, send and receive any ready packets.
Wait for events, send and receive any ready packets. If an event is in the queue it will be returned and dequeued. Generally you will want to dequeue all waiting events every frame.
Wait for a thread to finish.
Wait for a thread to finish. This call will block until the thread finishes.
Wait for and retrieve the value of a Channel message.
Wakes the body up or puts it to sleep.
We use the term flat table to denote a table which doesn't contain any other (nested) tables.
We use the term sequence to denote a table where the set of all positive numeric keys is equal to {1..n} for some integer n, which is called the length of the sequence (see §3.4.6).
Wether the window has mouse focus or not.
Wether to run the game in fullscreen (true) or windowed (false) mode. The fullscreen can also be toggled via love.window.setFullscreen or love.window.setMode.
What to do with the alpha of drawn objects when blending.
When a Thread is started, it only loads the love.thread module. Every other module has to be loaded with require.

When a fused game in release mode is run it will not save in the love save dir, but rather one for itself, whereas previously it would be %APPDATA%\\LOVE\\game on Windows, it now is %APPDATA%\\game. This concept applies to other platforms as well.
When a shape collides, the value set here will be passed to the collision callback as one of the parameters. Typically, you would want to store a table reference here, but any value can be used.

When an object is drawn, the pixel shader effect function is called hundreds or thousands of times: once for each pixel on the screen that the object touches. The pixel shader is run after the vertex shader, if there is one.

When beginning to write games using LÖVE, the most important parts of the API are the callbacks: love.load to do one-time setup of your game, love.update which is used to manage your game's state frame-to-frame, and love.draw which is used to render the game state onto the screen.
When called with "a/b" it creates both "a" and "a/b", if they don't exist already.

When called, each function will be passed three arguments. The first two arguments are the colliding fixtures and the third argument is the Contact between them. The postSolve callback additionally gets the normal and tangent impulse for each contact point. See notes.
When drawing content to a Canvas using regular alpha blending, the alpha values of the content get multiplied with its RGB values.

When gamma-correct rendering is enabled, many functions and objects perform automatic color conversion between sRGB and linear RGB in order for blending and shader math to be mathematically correct (which they aren't if it's not enabled.)
When in fill mode, the polygon must be convex and simple or rendering artifacts may occur. love.math.triangulate and love.math.isConvex can be used in 0.9.0+.

When relative mode is enabled, the cursor is hidden and doesn't move when the mouse does, but relative mouse motion events are still generated via love.mousemoved. This lets the mouse move in any direction indefinitely without the cursor getting stuck at the edges of the screen.

When stencil testing is enabled, the geometry of everything that is drawn afterward will be clipped / stencilled out based on a comparison between the arguments of this function and the stencil value of each pixel that the geometry touches. The stencil values of pixels are affected via love.graphics.stencil.
When this function is called with two numbers, dx, and dy, all the following drawing operations take effect as if their x and y coordinates were x+dx and y+dy.
Whether love.filesystem should follow symbolic links.
Whether multiple Canvases with different formats can be used in the same love.graphics.setCanvas call.
Whether repeat keypress events should be enabled when a key is held down.
Whether sleep is possible in the world.
Whether text input events are enabled.
Whether text input events should be enabled.
Whether the "lighten" and "darken" BlendModes are supported.
Whether the FileData can be loaded as CompressedImageData or not.
Whether the Image is stored as a compressed texture on the GPU.
Whether the Source was able to successfully start playing.
Whether the URL was opened successfully.
Whether the alpha color component is active when rendering.
Whether the archive will be searched when reading a filepath before or after already-mounted archives. This includes the game's source and save directories.
Whether the blue color component is active when rendering.
Whether the bodies in this world are allowed to sleep.
Whether the body should have fixed rotation.
Whether the buffer mode was successfully set.
Whether the file can be loaded as CompressedImageData or not.
Whether the file successfully flushed any buffered data to the disk.
Whether the font can render all the UTF-8 characters in the string.
Whether the font can render all the glyphs represented by the characters.
Whether the font can render all the glyphs represented by the codepoint numbers.
Whether the given polygon is convex.
Whether the graphics module is active and able to be used.
Whether the green color component is active when rendering.
Whether the icon has been set successfully.
Whether the identity directory will be searched when reading a filepath before or after the game's source directory and any currently.
Whether the message box should be attached to the love window or free-floating.
Whether the message box was successfully displayed.
Whether the red color component is active when rendering.
Whether the system has cursor functionality.
Whether the vertex attribute is used when drawing this Mesh.
Whether the virtual gamepad axis was successfully bound.
Whether the virtual gamepad button was successfully bound.
Whether this keypress event is a repeat. The delay between key repeats depends on the user's system settings.
Whether to continuously request attention until the window becomes active, or to do it only once.
Whether to discard the contents of the stencil buffer of the screen / active Canvas.
Whether to discard the texture(s) of the active Canvas(es) (the contents of the screen if no Canvas is active.)
Whether to enter or exit fullscreen mode.
Whether to include the screen's alpha channel in the ImageData. If false, the screenshot will be fully opaque.
Whether to try to load the video's audio into an audio Source. If not explicitly set to true or false, it will try without causing an error if the video has no audio.
Will be true if the world is in the process of updating its state.
Will return 2, when called like this:
Window is minimized or un-minimized by the user
Window mouse focus gained or lost
Window size changed by the user
Windows XP: C:\Documents and Settings\user\Application Data\LOVE\ or %appdata%\LOVE\

Wireframe mode should only be used for debugging. The lines drawn with it enabled do not behave like regular love.graphics lines: their widths don't scale with the coordinate transformations or with love.graphics.setLineWidth, and they don't use the smooth LineStyle.
With how many categories does this shape collide?
Wrap the line after this many horizontal pixels.
Write data to a file in the save directory. If the file existed already, it will be completely replaced by the new contents.
X coordinate of the rotation center.
X coordinate of the scaling center.
Y coordinate of the rotation center.
Y coordinate of the scaling center.
You can continue passing more point positions to create the PolygonShape.
You can continue passing point positions to draw a polyline.
You can continue passing values to the thread.
You can use the LÖVE logo as an example image.
You can visualise the pattern by reading the binary sequence backwards.
You can't draw CompressedImageData directly to the screen. See Image for that.
You can't draw ImageData directly to screen. See Image for that.
after the batch has been updated.
always has a constant value that is set when the gear joint is created.

as being in the sRGB color space. Everything drawn to the Canvas will be converted from linear RGB to sRGB. When the Canvas is drawn (or used in a shader), it will be decoded from sRGB to linear RGB. This reduces color banding when doing gamma-correct rendering, since sRGB encoding has more precision than linear RGB for darker colors.
as being in the sRGB color space. It will be decoded from sRGB to linear RGB when drawn or sampled from in a shader. For Canvases, this will also convert everything drawn
at a constant rate (+/- 3 per second in this example).
at their location when the world is updated (default)
bc5 Available since 0.9.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.10.0
be cleared when this function is called.
bmp Available since 0.8.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.10.0
call will be redirected to the Canvas and not shown on the screen.
call will be redirected to the specified canvases and not shown on the screen.
depending on the kind of event.
display the estimated amount of video memory used for textures
do conversions if gamma-correct rendering is actually enabled. The LOVE_GAMMA_CORRECT shader preprocessor define will be set if so.
dxt Available since 0.9.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.10.0
f Available since 0.7.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.8.0

flag is one of "reliable", "unsequenced", or "unreliable". Reliable packets are guaranteed to arrive, and arrive in the order in which they are sent. Unreliable packets arrive in the order in which they are sent, but they aren't guaranteed to arrive. Unsequenced packets are neither guaranteed to arrive, nor do they have any guarantee on the order they arrive. Optional. Defaults to reliable.
for all the images to be repeated, and using Quads of appropriate size will result in the best visual appearance.
function will check in love's filesystem.
hdrcanvas Available since 0.9.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.10.0
if a window is not open, or if the app is in the background on iOS. Typically the app's execution will be automatically paused by the system, in the latter case.
in the string, rather than the number of unicode characters. The Lua wiki and a presentation by one of Lua's creators give more in-depth explanations, with some tips.
jpg Available since 0.8.0 and removed in LÖVE 0.10.0
love.event.pump can only be called from the main thread, but afterwards, the rest of love.event can be used from any other thread.
